text: Nowgam is a major village located in the Shangus tehsil in Anantnag district of the Indian union territory of Jammu and Kashmir. It is located 11 km (6.8 mi) east of Anantnag and 74 km (46 mi) south of the Srinagar, the state capital.
The village is considered as the centre of commercial activities. It has grand Sports stadium named Shahi Hamdan Cricket Ground.

The main language spoken in the village is Kashmiri, though Urdu and Hindi are also widely understood. The population of Nowgam is more than 5682 consisting of about 51.37% males and 48.63% females. Agriculture is the main occupation of the people living there. It is situated along the foothills of the north western Himalaya Mountains and is located close to the  Khundroo Camp, which is among the largest military ammunition depots in North India. The literacy rate of the village is around above 85%, though there is a huge gender disparity between males and females. The etymology the village's name originates with the nine springs (or nine adjacent villages). The village is dominated by Kashmiri Muslims, though small communities of Hindus and Sikhs are also found in the village.

The 2025 Nowgam explosion was a major accidental blast that occurred on 14 November 2025 inside the Nowgam Police Station on the outskirts of Srinagar, in the Indian union territory of Jammu and Kashmir. The explosion happened while forensic and police teams were examining more than 300 kg of unstable explosive materials seized during an investigation into a suspected "white-collar" terror module. The blast killed nine people and injured between 27 and 32 others.
Indian authorities ruled out any militant involvement and called the incident an accidental detonation.

In early November 2025, security agencies in Haryana uncovered a suspected "white-collar" terror module and seized around 360 kg of explosive precursor materials, including ammonium nitrate, potassium nitrate, and sulphur. These materials were subsequently transferred to Nowgam Police Station for forensic analysis.
A joint team of forensic specialists, police personnel, and revenue officials assembled at the station on 14 November 2025 to examine the seized chemicals.
At approximately 23:20 IST, a powerful explosion ripped through the police station complex. CCTV footage showed a large fireball and shockwave that destroyed vehicles and damaged nearby buildings.
The blast triggered multiple smaller secondary explosions. Debris and human remains were found over 100 metres from the site.
Between 27 and 32 others were injured, including police personnel, forensic specialists, revenue officials, and civilians nearby.

Jammu & Kashmir DGP Nalin Prabhat described the incident as an accidental explosion caused by the instability of the seized material. No evidence of foul play or militant involvement was found in the initial investigation.
Forensic teams were deployed to determine the precise cause of the detonation.
The Jammu & Kashmir government announced compensation of ₹10 lakh for the families of the deceased and ₹1 lakh for those injured.
Security was tightened in the area, and a specialised investigation team was appointed to assess structural damage and review safety protocols.

Local leaders and civil society groups expressed grief and concern over the storage of large quantities of explosive materials within a police station located in a residential area. The incident reignited debate over safety procedures for handling seized explosives.
